4.
Since  the  beginning  of  the  transition  in  1990,  Mongolia  has  made  great  progress  in
developing a democratic form of government and a market-based economic system. During the
first four years of adjustment, the economy contracted sharply due to the withdrawal of Soviet
assistance, equivalent to about 30 percent of gross domestic product (GDP), and the breakup of
the trading system with the member countries of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance.
The  collapse  of  the  state  budget  led  to  drastic  cuts  in  subsidies  and  welfare  programs.
Furthermore, the economic restructuring and privatization process led to a severe retrenchment
in public sector employment, and to the closure of many nonviable enterprises. Although much
of  the  shed  labor  force  was  absorbed  by  the  extensive  livestock  sector,  and  in  part  by  the
growing  informal  economy,  unemployment  and  poverty  increased  rapidly.  Based  on  the

From 1994 to 1999 the economy recovered with real GDP growth averaging 3.6 percent.
The  source  of  growth  was  primarily  a  private  sector-led  recovery  in  the  agriculture  sector
following  the  privatization  of  livestock,  manufacturing,  and  services.  In  1996  the  Government
adopted  an  ambitious  reform  program  to  complete  the  transition  to  a  market  economy,
accelerate growth, and reduce poverty. Key elements of the program included reducing inflation,
liberalizing prices, streamlining the public sector, developing the private sector, and establishing
a  social  safety  net.  As  a  result,  private  sector  activity  increased  sharply  and  exports  grew  as
terms of trade improved in 1997. The exchange rate stabilized, and inflation fell from 47 percent
in 1996 to 20 percent in 1997. In 1997, Mongolia joined the World Trade Organization, and most
import taxes were abolished.

6.
In 1998 the terms of trade deteriorated resulting in lower tax revenues and undermining
bank loan portfolios, thus contributing to severe problems in the banking system. In addition, the
economy was affected by the financial crisis in the Asian countries and the Russian Federation.
Political uncertainty, resulting in two changes of government, undermined Mongolia's capacity to
respond  to  these  external  changes.  The  fiscal  deficit  widened  to  12  percent  of  GDP,  from  9
percent  in  1997,  and  the  togrog  (MNT)  depreciated  by  11  percent  against  the  dollar.  Despite
these external shocks and political crises, the economy continued to grow and inflation declined
to  6  percent.  But  the  number  of  households  living  below  the  poverty  line  remained  almost
unchanged,5 suggesting increasingly inequitable growth.

8.
According  to  the  Action  Plan  of  the  new  Government,  which  came  into  power  in  July
2000,  the  economic  policy  during  the  next  four  years  will  focus  on  continuing  and  deepening
economic  reform  and  accelerating  growth.  This  includes  ensuring  macroeconomic  stability;
setting  up  a  sound  banking  system    and  financial  sector;  continuing  the  privatization  process
and  improving  its  efficiency;  restoring  domestic  industries  including  the  crop  industry,  and
promoting  export,  in  particular  in  the  areas  of  livestock  raw  materials;  and  developing

9.

for the country's short- to medium-term economic prospects. The dependence of the economy
on the exports of a few primary commodities, such as copper, gold, and cashmere, makes the
country vulnerable to external shocks and contributes to the weakness of the external account.
The extremely harsh winter of 1999/2000 resulted in the loss of about 8 percent of Mongolia's

B.

Sector Description and Recent Performance

1.

Overview

Agriculture  is  the  mainstay  of  Mongolia's  2.4  million  people  and  contributes  a  third  of
10.
GDP.  Agricultural  and  agroprocessed  exports  amount  to  about  one  third  of  foreign  exchange
earnings. Agriculture is the source of employment for almost half of the population, and the most
important source of household income in rural areas. Extensive livestock production is by far the
dominant agricultural activity. Close to 80 percent of the country's total land area, or 128 million
hectares  (ha),  is  pasture  land.  The  remaining  20  percent  is  considered  inaccessible  due  to
mountain terrain or desert, or due to lack of water. Less than 1 percent of the land area, or 1.3
million  ha,  is  considered  arable.  The  continental  climate  with  a  short  growing  season,  sharply
defined  seasons,  mean  annual  temperatures  between  –6o  and  +4o  Celsius,  low  precipitation,
and  high  evapotranspiration  are  the  overriding  constraints  of  Mongolian  agriculture,  and  are
contributing factors to relatively fragile ecosystems.

11.
Mongolia's  agriculture  sector  comprises  (i)  a  livestock  subsector,  consisting  mainly  of
extensive livestock production based on the seasonal migration of mixed herds of sheep, goats,
cattle,  horses,  and  camels;  and  some  intensive  livestock  production  with  housed  dairy  cattle,
pigs, and poultry; and (ii) a crop subsector concentrated on the production of wheat, the main
staple  food.  Crop  production  mostly  takes  place  on  relatively  large,  extensively  managed  and
mechanized  farms  in  the  north-central  region  around  Ulaanbaatar.  Horticulture  production
comprises  mostly  potato  and  vegetables,  and  is  increasingly  based  on  small  family  plots  and
some commercial greenhouses.

12.
The  transition  process  had  a  dramatic  impact  on  agriculture.  With  the  removal  of  the
support  structure  previously  provided  by  the  state,  the  agriculture  sector  contracted  sharply  in
the early 1990s. However, by 1995 it had recovered to its 1989 level in real terms, and in 1998 it
was  14  percent  above  this.  In  contrast,  GDP  in  1995  was  only  84  percent,  and  in  1998,  93
percent of its 1989 level in real terms (Appendix 2, Table A2.1). The relatively quick restoration
of agricultural output helped to prevent a far worse economic contraction in the initial years of
adjustment. In current prices, agriculture accounted for 15 percent of GDP in 1989. Agriculture's
share  rose  to  37  percent  in  1994,  the  first  year  of  economic  recovery.  Since  then  it  declined
slightly  to  33  percent  in  1998.  In  real  terms,  the  share  of  agriculture  in  GDP  varied  less
dramatically,  staying  at  around  37  percent  since  1995,  compared  with  30  percent  in  1989.
Within  agricultural  output,  the  share  of  the  livestock  subsector  increased  from  77  percent  in
1989 to 90 percent in 1999, while the share of the crop subsector declined from 23 percent to
10 percent. Employment in agriculture rose significantly, from 33 percent of total employment in
1990 to about half in 1999.

13.
Even  though  agricultural  production  and  employment  increased  during  the  1990s,  the
linkages between the agriculture and industry sectors significantly declined. In 1989 more than
half of industrial output was directly based on agriculture. By the end of the decade, this share
had decreased, both absolutely (to about 25 percent of its 1989 level) and relatively (to about a
quarter of the total in 1989).

 2.

Crop Subsector

4

14.
During the late 1980s Mongolia was more than self-sufficient in wheat. For many years
large state subsidies had stimulated the conversion of pasture land to cropped land, including in
very marginal areas. In 1989, 530,000 ha was sown with wheat.6 By 1999 this had declined by
almost a half to 273,000 ha (Appendix 2, Table A2.2). The areas planted to other crops, such as
potatoes  and  fodder,  had  also  declined  considerably.  As  a  result,  crop  output  in  1999  was
significantly below 1989 levels. Wheat output was a quarter, and fodder output 1 percent of the
1989  level.  Only  potato  and  vegetable  output  showed  some  increase  in  the  last  few  years.
Average yields also declined significantly during the 1990s. Wheat yield fell from 1.3 tons per ha
in 1989 to 0.6 tons per ha in 1999, although yields varied widely across provinces (from 0.17 ton
to 1.5 tons per ha) and across farms, with some farms reaching over 2.5 ton per ha.

Poor  seeds  are  a  major  contributing  factor  for  low  yields.  For  several  years,  little
15.
commercial seed was available in the market; farmers used farm-saved seed of poor quality and
outdated  varieties.  Other  factors  include  exhausted  soils,  little  use  of  fertilizers  or  pesticides,
and failing machinery. While the demand for credit is high, in particular to buy inputs and minor
equipment  at  the  beginning  of  the  cropping  season,  little  credit  has  been  available  for  crop
farmers over the last few years. The limited expertise of some of the new, private farmers also
has contributed to the decline in yields.

16.
By  1999,  most  of  the  state  farms  were  fully  privatized,  with  about  80  percent  under
single  (either  individual  or  company)  ownership.  There  are  now  about  300  farms  with  several
thousand ha and many smaller farms with several hundred ha. An increasing share of vegetable
production is taking place on small plots by households, mostly near urban centers. Vegetables
are also grown commercially on some of the irrigated land, currently about 4,200 ha.

17.
In the pretransition period, processing of crops largely involved the milling of wheat into
flour  and  its  use  for  bread  and  bakery  production;  the  distilling  for  alcohol,  spirits,  and  other
beverage  manufacture;  and  the  production  of  manufactured  fodder.  During  the  1990s
processing  activities  fell  sharply.  Flour  production  is  now  a  third,  and  bread  and  bakery
production a quarter of their 1989 level. Manufactured fodder in 1998 was at 10 percent of the
1989 level, largely due to the collapse of intensive livestock production. Only alcohol output has
risen above pretransition levels.

18.
Exports  of  crop  products  have  essentially  disappeared,  while  imports  including  wheat,
flour, potatoes, and vegetables are steadily increasing, and now account for about 10 percent of
total imports. The import requirements for wheat in 1999 amounted to more than 50 percent of
the  country's  wheat  needs.  During  the  1990s,  wheat  and  flour  imports  have  largely  been
commodity aid-funded by the United States (US) and Japan.

3.

Livestock Subsector

a.

Privatization and Production

small number of animals for personal use. The negdels employed herders as salaried workers,
provided  the  necessary  supplies  and  technical  advice,  marketed  the  produce,  and  offered
various  social  and  cultural  benefits.  During  the  first  wave  of  privatization  in  1990/91  the

20.
In  contrast  to  the  extensive  livestock  subsector,  intensive  livestock  production  has
experienced  a  sharp  decline.  With  their  reliance  on  imported  high  supplement  feed,  exotic

Processing  of  livestock  products  strongly  declined  during  the  1990s.  Meat  products  in
21.
1999  amounted  to  only  10  percent  of  their  1989  level.  Similar  declines  occurred  in  the
processing of fibers (cashmere, camel hair, and wool) and hides and skins (cattle, horse, goat,
and sheep). Export of many livestock products also dramatically declined. Meat exports fell from
30,500 tons in 1989 to 2,200 tons in 1995, and then recovered to 7,500 tons in 1999. However,
export of unprocessed cashmere, and hides and skins in raw form continues to do well.

b.

Livestock Disaster During the Severe Winter

22.
The continuous increase in livestock numbers over a favorable climatic period during the
1990s came to a dramatic halt in the winter of 1999/2000. Following an unusually dry summer,
the winter of 1999/2000 was very harsh. Early and heavy snowfall in September-October 1999
continued  to  build  up  and  denied  livestock  access  to  limited  forage.  Weakened  by  starvation,
about 2.7 million livestock or 8 percent of the total stock did not survive the cold. An estimated
50,000 households were affected by livestock losses; many were households with small herds
and little experience in herding. About 2,000 households lost all their livestock.

23.
In the early phase of the disaster, the Government released strategic reserves of fodder
and  fuel  to  affected  provinces,  and  distributed  relief  items  such  as  flour  and  tea.  The  State
Emergency  Commission  organized  the  delivery  of  hay  and  fodder  to  the  worst  hit  areas.  In
February 2000, the Government launched an appeal for national and international donations to
assist the herder population. Numerous nongovernment organizations (NGOs), embassies, and
international  organizations  responded.  Short-term  relief  measures  until  June  2000  focused  on
supporting affected herder households and their livestock in overcoming the immediate effects
of  disaster.  Since  July  2000  affected  herder  households  have  been  helped  to  restock  their
decimated herds and stock up food and fodder reserves for the winter.

C.

Constraints and Issues

24.
Major  agricultural  reforms  introduced  by  the  Government  in  the  first  half  of  the  1990s
included the privatization of state farms and negdels, deregulation of prices of major agricultural
products,  and  liberalization  of  agricultural  trade.  These  policy  and  institutional  reforms  were
supported  by  the  ASP  (footnote  1).  From  1996  onward,  adopted  reforms  focused  on
macroeconomic  stabilization,  reduction  of  the  public  sector,  and  private  sector  development.
Despite  substantial  progress  with  reform,  key  constraints  and  issues  remain  that  undermine
agricultural performance.

 1.

Private Sector Activity

6

25.
During the 1990s almost all livestock and most crop farms were privatized. This process
now  needs  to  be  completed  with  the  privatization  of  the  remaining  crop  farms  which  have
significant national or provincial government shareholdings.

26.
The  changes  in  ownership  structure  have  frequently  failed  to  yield  significant
improvements  in  productivity  and  profitability.  This  is  mainly  because  the  supply  of  inputs,  the
processing  and  marketing  of  outputs,  and  the  provision  of  financial  services,  which  previously
were  organized  and  controlled  by  the  state,  deteriorated  and  left  a  vacuum  that  has  not  been
adequately filled by the private sector. Also many of the new owners have little knowledge, and
received little advice, on how to manage their assets. Although Mongolia's human resources are
high  in  literacy  and  technical  disciplines,  they  are  limited  in  terms  of  entrepreneurial  attitudes
and  skills,  accounting,  marketing,  and  other  market-oriented  business  practices.  Increasingly,
the cooperative movement is seen as providing an important avenue to strengthen the needed
human resource skills and management capacity.

27.
The privatization of state-owned enterprises involved in the processing of livestock and
crop products proceeded much slower than that of livestock and crop farms. In the pretransition
period  agricultural  processing  was  concentrated  in  a  few,  large  enterprises,  some  of  which
continue to have the state as the major shareholder and hold a dominant market position. With
the collapse of traditional export markets, major agricultural processors are now operating at low
capacity,  seriously  constraining  their  ability  to  service  debts  and,  for  state-owned  enterprises,
undermining  privatization  attempts.  In  addition,  several  large-scale  enterprises  that  were
developed  with  the  assistance  of  Council  of  Mutual  Economic  Assistance  countries,  such  as
wool  spinning,  knitting,  shoe  making,  and  leather  factories,  became  unviable  with  the  end  of
central  planning  and  had  to  shut  down.  As  a  result,  most  of  the  wool,  hides,  and  skins,  and
about half of the cashmere are now exported in raw form. Efforts are needed to help enterprises
remaining  in  the  public  sector,  such  as  Biokombinat,  a  factory  which  produces  vaccines  for
combating animal diseases, to operate autonomously and compete fairly with the private sector.

28.
The entry of new privately owned trading and processing enterprises has been slow due
to the limited availability of investment and working capital, and the overly centralized structure
of the remaining processing industry. However, the share of small- and medium-sized privately
owned  plants  is  gradually  increasing,  and  in  some  areas,  such  as  cashmere  and  flour
processing,  becoming  large  enough  to  challenge  the  market  power  of  the  large  processors.
Most  of  the  investment  activities  are  taking  place  in  a  few  urban  centers,  indicating  a  role  for
carefully structured support programs to promote investment activities in more remote areas.

2.

Trade Regime and Taxation

29.
The  liberalization  of  the  trade  regime  contributed  to  establishing  a  more  competitive
position  for  the  country's  domestic  production.  In  the  mid-1990s,  Mongolia  had  a  free  trade
regime  with  zero  import  duties  and  no  nontariff  barriers.  This  policy  was  partially  reversed  in
1999  when  a  discriminatory  trade  regime  with  tariffs  ranging  from  zero  to  15  percent  was
reintroduced, with the 15 percent rate levied seasonally on wheat, potatoes, and vegetables. An
export tax on raw cashmere was adopted in 1997. Cumbersome and nontransparent customs
controls  and  export  licensing  practices  also  tax  agricultural  exports.  To  encourage  export
growth,  clear  procedures  need  to  be  established  for  applications  for  and  issuance  of  export
licenses for agricultural products.

 7

30.
Currently the option of raising certain import duties and export taxes is under discussion,
in part due to the need to contain the fiscal deficit. However, transport costs alone constitute an
enormous penalty to Mongolian trade, and offer high rates of equivalent protection to domestic
production.  Another  option,  in  the  longer  term,  would  be  to  broaden  the  tax  base.  Agriculture
currently  accounts  for  about  a  third  of  GDP,  but  due  to  broad,  nontargeted  tax  exemptions
contributes  only  a  small  share  of  the  national  tax  revenue.  However,  as  the  tax  base  is
broadened, tax incentives need to be rationalized to encourage investment in rural areas.

3.

Agricultural Marketing System

31.
The privatization of livestock and crop farms was carried out before the restructuring of
input and output marketing, which is needed to provide incentives and channels for increased
agricultural  activity.  Partly  because  of  market  logistics  and  low  monetization,  subsistence
production in rural areas, barter transactions, and in-kind wage payments are common. With a
shortage of cash and a high-risk production environment, producers are reluctant to use inputs
that are not absolutely necessary. This, together with the lack of price differentiation for higher
quality raw materials, is contributing to low productivity and poor product quality.

32.
Processing  plants,  especially  for  livestock  raw  materials,  use  a  system  of  procurement
agents  and  act  as  monopsonistic  buyers  in  small  rural  markets.  Producers  often  receive  not
cash but kind, usually in the form of household consumption goods on which the terms of trade
are  heavily  skewed  in  favor  of  the  agents.  Many  herder  households  are  isolated  during  the
summer when most buying takes place, and have little price information or access to markets.
The agent's willingness to buy small quantities of fiber or a few animals for trekking to slaughter
can be attractive to a herder with only a few animals and little market power. So far agricultural
producers  have  received  limited  advice  on  how  to  cooperate  to  improve  their  bargaining
position. However, in some regions cooperative marketing is increasingly being used to improve
returns for producers.

33.
The marketing of agricultural raw materials follows a highly seasonal pattern. Cashmere
is usually marketed in May, wool in July, wheat in September, and livestock in autumn. Due to a
lack of working capital, many processing plants have difficulty acquiring the desired amount and
quality  of  raw  materials  when  they  are  offered.  In  addition,  processors  in  the  crop  subsector
have  difficulty  competing  with  imported  goods,  and  many  livestock  processors  have  yet  to
reestablish their export channels. Export opportunities in the meat and meat products industries
are particularly constrained by the absence of standards and qualified, licensed veterinarians to
supervise meat hygiene and production.

4.

Cooperative System

34. When the negdels were privatized in the early 1990s, some ceased to exist, some were
restructured  into  other  legal  forms,  and  the  remainder  were  established  as  cooperatives.  New
cooperatives have also been formed. Currently about 1,300 entities at the primary level have a
total membership of about 5 percent of the Mongolian population. More than two thirds of these
entities are cooperatives, and a quarter of them are agricultural cooperatives. The cooperatives
are  organized  in  seven  cooperative  associations  covering  agriculture  (mainly  livestock),  small-
scale industry and trade, and savings and credit services. Supplementary Appendix A provides
an overview of the cooperative system and the activities of cooperatives and their associations.

35.
By  the  mid-1990s,  many  households,  especially  in  rural  areas,  were  not  able  to
participate in the emerging market economy. By working on their own and often in isolation, they
had few opportunities to pool limited resources and develop favorable market structures. Some

 8

of the new herders households who had received livestock during the negdel privatization also
lacked  the  professional  background  to  manage  these  assets.  Similar  to  other  transition
countries,  this  situation  created  new  interest  in  cooperatives.  When  asked  about  their  most
pressing  needs,  herder  and  cultivator  households,  especially  in  more  remote  areas,  often
emphasize that besides improved access to financial services they need better marketing and
input supply channels. They are aware that when they bargain on their own with private traders
they  are  receiving  relatively  low  prices  for  their  produce,  while  they  pay  high  prices  for  inputs
and  consumer  goods.  Many  realize  that  their  agricultural  activities  could  be  improved  if  they
organized  themselves  into  groups  which  needed  to  be  larger  than  their  extended  family.
Cooperatives are seen by many agricultural and other rural producers as having the potential to
expand  the  local  organizational  basis  needed  for  economically  viable  activities,  such  as
marketing and processing, thereby providing greater income security and higher returns to their
members.

36.
In some regions cooperatives and their associations are now increasing their activities to
improve  services  and  provide  collective  income-earning  opportunities  for  their  members.
However,  the  expansion  of  cooperative  activities  is  currently  limited  by  several  constraints.
Many  rural  households  still  have  limited  knowledge  about  cooperative  activities  in  a  market
economy.  Also  cooperatives  have  limited  access  to  operating  capital,  necessary  for  their
marketing  activities,  and  to  investment  capital,  needed  to  improve  production,  marketing,  and
processing facilities. Many cooperatives also lack the knowledge to prepare business plans and
the financial expertise to effectively use credit. Due to human resource and funding constraints,
the internal management of cooperatives and their cooperative associations is also often weak,
and the provision of vital services such as accounting and auditing is limited. The tax treatment
of  cooperatives  also  requires  significant  rationalization.  In  more  remote  areas,  communication
and  transport  problems  pose  serious  constraints  to  cooperative  development.  The  legislative
and  regulatory  framework  for  the  development  of  cooperatives  was  significantly  strengthened
with the adoption of the Cooperative Law and the Cooperative Development Program in 1998;
however, the program remains largely unimplemented.

6.

Institutional Capacity and Governance

41.
During  the  last  decade,  a  series  of  major  changes  were  introduced  regarding  the
institutional  setup  of  agricultural  and  agriculture-related  agencies  nationally  and  locally.  In  a
devolution  of  administrative  control  to  the  local  level  during  the  early  1990s,  the  Government
transferred several agricultural functions to the 22 provincial governments. In 1996, the Ministry
of Food and Agriculture and the Ministry of Industry were amalgamated to form the Ministry of
Agriculture  and  Industry.  The  structure  of  Government  agricultural  support  services  was
rationalized  and  grouped  in  either  implementing  or  regulatory  functions  within  two  main
agencies under the ministry. These organizational changes were accompanied with a significant
reduction  in  the  number  of  staff.  In  addition,  fiscal  constraints  resulted  in  reduced  nonsalary

7.

Agricultural Support Services

43. With the institutional changes during the last few years, the emphasis on cost recovery
for  agricultural  support  services  has  increased.  But  producers  often  find  it  difficult  to  avail  of
these services because of limited cash availability, the high cost of credit, and adverse terms-of-
trade  between  agricultural  inputs  and  outputs.  The  outreach  of  MFA’s  agricultural  extension
center is severely curtailed by the lack of staff and budgetary resources. Agricultural research is
similarly  weak.  It  provides  little  tangible  support  to  extension  services,  and  is  not  oriented  to
meeting  the  demand  of  agricultural  producers  or  processors.  To  support  private  sector
development, agricultural research services need to be responsive to the demands of producers
and processors, and adequately organized and funded. Some success has been achieved with
the Green Revolution Program, approved in 1997, which aims to improve supplementary food
and income to low income families by assisting with potato and vegetable production. It relies on
the  lower  levels  of  Government  as  well  as  on  the  initiatives  of  schools  and  NGOs  in  the
countryside.  It  is  credited  as  having  contributed  to  the  increased  potato  and  vegetable
production that occurred in the second half of the 1990s. The Green Revolution Program can be
enhanced  by  (i)  strengthening  the  involvement  of  NGOs  by  awarding  them  contracts  for
program  implementation,  (ii)  focusing  benefits  on  vulnerable  groups,  (iii)  including  a  broader
range  of  activities,  (iv)  introducing  cost  recovery,  and  (v)  establishing  a  mechanism  at  the
provincial  level  to  ensure  that  the  different  programs  targeted  at  vulnerable  groups  are
coordinated.

44.
Veterinary  and  breeding  services  are  partly  privatized,  but  public-private  partnership
arrangements are still being adjusted with little progress to date. The professionalism of private
veterinary practitioners needs to be upgraded, and the system of their remuneration revised to
reflect their role as service providers in a market economy. In the area of vaccination policy, the
Government must concentrate its limited resources on effective control of a limited range of key
diseases  rather  than  pursuing  an  ineffective  program  aimed  at  the  complete  coverage  of
livestock  diseases.  Some  efforts  have  been  undertaken  to  introduce  commercial  seed
multiplication  but  this  has  had  little  impact  on  the  availability  of  quality  seed,  and  farmers  are
forced  to  use  farm-saved  seed  of  poor  quality  and  outdated  varieties.  Due  to  poor
communication channels in rural areas, many agricultural producers have no access to market
information.  This  together  with  the  limited  availability  and  affordability  of  suitable  support
services is a major constraint to improving agricultural productivity and the quality of products.

 8.

Social Transformation

11

45.
Under central planning, unemployment and poverty were virtually unknown. Cutbacks in
public expenditure during the transition period led to a sharp decline in social services and jobs
in provincial and district centers, and to an increase in the number of people considered to be
poor. This was accompanied by a shift in population to rural areas. From 1990 to 1999, the rural
population increased from 40 percent of the total population to almost 50 percent. People have
also  been  moving  out  of  the  provincial  centers  and  minor  towns  either  to  Ulaanbaatar,  which
has grown by 16 percent since 1990, or to the countryside. In rural areas the extensive livestock
sector  has  been  functioning  as  an  informal  safety  net  in  times  of  limited  formal  employment
opportunities.

46.
The privatization of the negdel livestock together with the population shift to rural areas
resulted  in  a  nearly  threefold  increase  in  the  number  of  herders  (from  148,000  in  1990  to
418,000  in  1999).  Similarly,  the  number  of  households  whose  primary  source  of  income  is
derived from herding more than doubled (from 69,000 in 1989 to 197,000 in 1998) and is now
equivalent to about 40 percent of the population. Strengthened by the overall growth in livestock
numbers,  herd  size  has  increased  substantially.  Following  privatization  in  1990,  about  80
percent  of  households  with  livestock  owned  less  than  50  animals,  and  only  4  percent  owned
more  than  100  animals.10  By  1999,  the  number  of  households  with  less  than  50  animals
declined to 36 percent, and the number of households with more than 100 animals increased to
41  percent.  In  addition,  the  spread  of  households'  herd  sizes  increased.  In  1999  more  than
1,200  households  had  more  than  1,000  animals;  the  majority  of  herder  households  had  only
enough  animals  to  live  on  a  subsistence  basis.  Many  of  the  people  who  moved  to  the
countryside to become new herders have small, marginally viable herds and limited skills, and
are most vulnerable to natural disasters and other risks.

9.

Pasture and Well Management

47.
During  the  last  decade,  pressure  on  pastures  has  been  widespread  and  increasing
because  of  the  significant  changes  in  the  size,  structure,  and  management  of  the  extensive
livestock  subsector.  The  national  herd  grew  by  about  8  million  head,  or  19  million  sheep
equivalent units (SEU),11 and the average stocking rate increased from 0.34 SEU per ha to 0.46
SEU  per  ha.  The  main  reasons  for  the  growth  in  livestock  number  include  the  need  of  an
increasing number of herder households to secure their livelihood, the general perception that
more livestock will increase economic security, the lack of marketing channels  to sell animals
and the limited export demand, a large increase in the price for cashmere, and the absence of a
weather-induced catastrophe until the winter of 1999/2000.

48.
Overgrazing  and  the  loss  of  pasture  productivity  was  recognized  prior  to  1990,  and
attempts  were  made  to  address  the  problem  by  (i)  large-scale  provision  of  supplementary
fodder by the state; (ii) heavy investment in the development of wells, bores, and pumps to open
up  previously  underutilized  grazing  land  by  providing  reliable  stock-watering  facilities;  and  (iii)
controls on the movement of herders, mostly within a particular district, relying on the authority
of  negdel  managers  and  the  district  governor.  During  the  1990s  these  measures  were
discontinued.  As  a  result,  the  fodder  supply  industry  has  almost  disappeared.  More  than  40

10.

Risk Management

50.
Under central planning the state provided a comprehensive risk management system for
agricultural  producers,  including  continuous  training  and  advice,  salaries,  livestock  insurance,
emergency fodder supplies, radio communication channels covering almost all of the country's
districts, and national and local emergency plans, which included transport facilities for herder
households and their animals in times of natural disasters. During the last decade this support
structure ceased to exist, and agricultural producers were forced to individually shoulder all risk
associated with agricultural production in a harsh environment. The severity of the effects of the
livestock  disaster  of  the  winter  of  1999/2000  are  to  a  large  extent  a  result  of  the  loss  of  the
previous risk management system.

51.
In addition to the short-term causes of the livestock disaster, i.e., a dry summer followed
by  an  early,  cold,  and  snowy  winter,  several  medium-  to  long-  term  causes  contributed
significantly  to  the  large  impact.  They  include  the  inflow  of  inexperienced  persons  to  the
extensive  livestock  subsector  and  the  concomitant  emergence  of  many  relatively  small  and
economically unsustainable herds, the unbalanced composition and growth of herds, increasing
parasite loads due to limited veterinary services, uncontrolled breeding, the lack of reserves of
hay  and  animal  feed,  shrinking  grazing  areas  due  to  the  lack  of  stock-watering  points,  the
concentration  of  livestock  in  areas  around  market  centers,  the  breakdown  of  communication
channels  in  rural  areas,  and  related  to  that,  inadequate  early  warning  systems  and  disaster
management planning.

Government Objectives and Strategy

54.
The  Action  Plan  of  the  new  Government  adopted  in  September  2000  outlines  key
objectives  in  several  policy  areas,  including  economic  policy,  social  policy,  and  regional  and
rural  development  policy.  A  key  objective  in  the  area  of  economic  policy  is  to  continue  and
deepen  economic  reform  and  accelerate  economic  growth  by  (i)  ensuring  macroeconomic

promoting export (in particular in the areas of livestock raw materials such as meat, fibers, skin,
and hides), preventing a further decline in the crop industry, and intensifying the implementation

a key element is the goal to reduce the number of households living under the poverty line by

The medium-term objectives for regional and rural development focus on improving the
living standards of people in rural areas through economic development, infrastructure, as well

ADB's Operations and Strategy in the Sector

1.

Country Operational Strategy

59.
ADB's  first  country  operational  strategy  (COS)  for  Mongolia  was  adopted  in  1994.  Its
main  aim  was  to  facilitate  the  country's  transition  to  a  market  economy  and  to  stimulate
economic  growth.  In  the  agriculture  sector,  the  focus  was  mainly  on  improving  the  policy  and
institutional  environment.  During  the  period  covered  by  the  first  COS,  Mongolia  implemented
substantial  reforms  and  experienced  reasonable  growth  rates.  But  economic  growth  did  not
result in a significant reduction in the number of people living below the poverty line.

60.
The new COS endorsed in March 2000 is placing poverty reduction at the same level of
importance as the need to stimulate economic growth. The main objective is to foster economic
growth  and  reduce  poverty  by  focusing  on  income  and  employment  generation  by  developing
the  private  sector.  The  strategy  emphasizes  the  need  to  promote  good  governance  as  an
overarching objective. ADB interventions are to be guided by the main objective of growth with
poverty  reduction.  Of  the  five  core  sectors  identified  for  ADB  support,  agriculture  has  the
potential  to  (i)  support  private  sector-led  expansion  of  economic  activity,  (ii)  strengthen  the
enabling  legal  and  regulatory  environment  to  stimulate  private  sector  activity,  (iii)  improve
support services to overcome constraints to agricultural development, (iv) promote the improved
provision of financial services in rural areas, and (v) support improvements in land tenure.

summarized  in  the  Partnership  Agreement  signed  in  March  2000.  The  Partnership  Agreement

IV.

THE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM

A. 

Rationale

66.
Mongolia's  transition  from  a  centrally  planned  to  a  market-oriented  system  during  the
1990s has had a dramatic impact on the agriculture sector. With the removal of large subsidies
previously  provided  by  the  state,  the  agriculture  sector  contracted  sharply  in  the  early  1990s.
However,  by  the  mid-1990s  agriculture  had  restored  output  to  pretransition  levels,  and  thus
helped to prevent a far worse contraction of the economy in the initial years of the transition.

67.
Even though the agriculture sector, in particular the extensive livestock subsector, was
able  to  support  the  economy  during  the  most  difficult  years,  several  factors  continue  to
undermine  its  performance.  This  is  despite  the  implementation  of  major  market  reforms,
including  privatization,  deregulation  of  prices  of  agricultural  products,  and  liberalization  of
agricultural trade. It is becoming increasingly apparent that while almost all livestock and most
crop farms have been privatized, many of the new owners have little knowledge, and have not
been  taught  how  to  manage  their  assets  in  a  market  economy.  The  supply  of  critical  support
services,  which  was  previously  organized  and  controlled  by  the  state,  deteriorated  and  left  a
vacuum that has not yet been adequately filled by the private sector. While the financial sector
is being restructured with substantial external assistance, very little lending is provided in rural
areas.  The  limited  availability  of  credit  in  the  countryside  and  the  high-risk  production
environment of Mongolia's agriculture sector negatively affect the demand for support services.
The supply of support services such as research and extension is weak due to lack of staff and
budget resources. Other support services, such as veterinary services, are partly privatized but
public-private partnership arrangements are still being adjusted with little progress to date. As a
result of the limited availability and use of support services and other inputs, the productivity of
many agricultural enterprises is very low. In the livestock subsector the problem is intensified by
the overgrazing of many pastures as a result of the substantial increase in the national herd and
the large number of inoperative stock-watering wells.

68.
Closely  related  to  the  problem  of  low  productivity  is  the  lack  of  marketing  channels
needed  to  increase  incentives  for  agricultural  activity.  The  restructuring  of  marketing  and  the
privatization  of  processing  enterprises  has  proceeded  much  slower  than  the  privatization  of
livestock  collectives  and  state  farms.  With  the  collapse  of  traditional  export  markets  and  the
reduction  of  subsidies,  many  agricultural  processing  plants  have  been  closed,  and  the
remaining  are  operating  with  low  capacity.  The  entry  of  private  trading  and  processing
enterprises has been slow due to the lack of investment and working capital. Partly because of
market  logistics  and  low  monetization  in  rural  areas,  subsistence  production  and  barter
transactions  are  now  common.  Due  to  poor  communication  links,  many  agricultural  producers
have  little  access  to  market  and  other  information.  The  cooperative  system,  which  offers  the
most  promising  avenue  for  the  provision  of  marketing  and  other  services,  the  delivery  of  local

 17

public  goods,  and  collective  income-earning  activities  in  rural  areas  is  only  recently  receiving
increasing attention.

69.
To  address  these  two  main  problem  areas,  i.e.,  low  productivity  and  limited  marketing
channels,  and  the  resulting  constraints  on  income-earning  opportunities  in  rural  areas,  a  two-
pronged approach is required. This involves (i) the deepening and refinement of the policy and
legal framework for agriculture, and (ii) the improved provision of support services for production
and marketing as well as credit. Thus, the ASDP will integrate a policy loan with targeted policy
actions, and an investment loan providing support in the two main problem areas.

B.

Objectives and Scope

70.
The  sector  goals  are  to  develop  a  more  market-oriented,  efficient,  and  sustainable
agriculture sector and reduce poverty by providing increased income opportunities. The specific
purpose  is  to  increase  productivity  and  profitability  of  agricultural  producers.  The  primary
strategic  development  objective  is  economic  growth,  and  the  secondary  objective  is  poverty
reduction. The ASDP will include both direct and indirect poverty interventions, and poor people
are  expected  to  comprise  at  least  one  third  of  the  beneficiaries.  The  emphasis  on  poverty
reduction  is  in  line  with  the  COS  for  Mongolia,  the  Partnership  Agreement,  and  the
Government's Action Plan.

71.
The  ASDP  comprises  a  policy  reform  agenda  with  seven  policy  areas,  and  the
investment  Project  with  three  components.  Associated  with  the  ASDP  will  be  TA  for  Capacity
Building in Agriculture.

E.

The Investment Project

1.

Project Description

75.
Linked closely to these policy reforms, the investment Project will focus on delivering an
integrated  package  of  critical  support  services  to  improve  productivity  and  profitability  in  the
agriculture  sector.  The  Project  will  be  implemented  over  five  years,  and  include  three
components: (i) production and marketing support, (ii) credit, and (iii) project management. The
design  of  the  components  has  also  been  guided  by  the  need  for  medium-  to  longer-term
measures  to  help  reduce  the  vulnerability  of  the  agriculture  sector  to  natural  disasters  (paras.
51-52).

 19

The  activities  of  the  three  components  will  focus  on  four  provinces  in  the  relatively
76.
remote  and  poor  western  part  of  Mongolia:  Dzavhan,  Hovd,  Gobialtay,  and  Urs.  The  credit
component  will  also  cover  the  north-central  provinces  of  Darhan-Uul  and  Selenge,  which
comprise the country's most important wheat producing area. An overview of the six provinces
is in Appendix 5.

77.
The  four  western  provinces  comprise  about  a  quarter  of  the  country's  land  area  and
livestock, and 15 percent of the population. Due to the arid nature of the environment, the most
important  agricultural  activity  is  extensive  livestock  production.  Crop  and  fodder  production
declined  drastically  during  the  1990s.  Only  vegetable  production  is  now  higher  than  in  the
pretransition  period  (except  in  Dzavhan).  During  the  livestock  disaster  in  the  winter  of
1999/2000, Urs and Dzavhan were the third and fourth most affected provinces in the country,
while Hovd and Gobialtay were relatively little affected.

78.
The standard of living in the four western provinces is generally lower than in the more
centrally  located  provinces.  Three  of  the  four  western  provinces  are  among  the  poorest
provinces in Mongolia, with Hovd being the second, Dzavhan the third, and Urs the fifth poorest.
According  to  the  Government's  income-based  poverty  line,  the  population  living  below  the
minimum  standard  level  in  these  three  provinces  in  1998  was  43  percent,  41  percent,  and  34
percent  (the  national  average  was  26  percent).  A  main  reason  for  the  large  number  of  poor
people in the three provinces is the high percentage of households with small herds. Although
their  number  is  declining,  in  1999  more  than  half  of  all  households  with  animals  in  Hovd,
Dzavhan, and Urs had less than 100 animals. By contrast, in Gobialtay, where 16 percent of the
people were living below the poverty line, less than 40 percent of the households with livestock
had less than 100 animals.

79.
The  credit  component  will  cover  the  four  western  provinces  and  two  north-central
provinces: Darhan-Uul and Selenge. The extension of the credit component to Darhan-Uul and
Selenge  will,  among  others,  facilitate  increased  wheat  production  and  productivity  in  the
country's major wheat-producing area. The low level of wheat production and the continuing rise
of flour and wheat imports to supply domestic demand have led to growing Government concern
about  food  security.  However,  the  credit  component  in  Darhan-Uul  and  Selenge  will  not  be
limited to wheat farmers. A summary of the three project components follows.

a.

Production and Marketing Support Component

80.
The production and marketing support component includes assistance for (i) expanding
small-scale  horticulture  production  among  vulnerable  groups  under  the  Green  Revolution
Program;  (ii)  strengthening  veterinary  services;  (iii)  rehabilitating  wells;  (iv)  developing  the
cooperative  system  to  provide  better  marketing  and  processing  services  to  agricultural
producers;  and  (v)  improving  rural  communication  channels,  including  telephone  and  radio
services.

i.

Green Revolution Program

81.
The  Project  will  strengthen  and  reorient  MFA's  Green  Revolution  Program  in  the  four
western provinces. Advice will be provided not only on the production of a few vegetables but
also  on  other  horticultural  products,  as  well  as  on  opportunities  for  storage,  processing,  and
marketing. The subcomponent will focus on vulnerable groups, including households headed by
women and the unemployed in the provincial and district centers, households with small herds
that graze around these centers, as well as households affected by the livestock disaster during

 20

the  winter  of  1999/2000.  The  promotion  of  horticultural  activities  will  enable  these  groups  to
improve their food security and diversify incomes by marketing their surplus produce.

82.
At  the  national  level,  support  will  be  provided  for  workshops  for  provincial  Green
Revolution representatives and for preparing more information material and advice in the areas
of horticulture, marketing and processing, and business practices for dissemination at the local
level.  At  the  provincial  level,  funds  will  be  provided  for  the  enhancement  of  the  agroparks,
training  for  district  agronomists,  workshops,  involvement  of  NGOs  in  market  surveys  and
advisory services, and various promotional activities such as agricultural shows. Assistance will
also be provided to send farmers to see successful ventures in other districts, and to experiment

demonstrations  and  advice,  and  training  to  farmers.  These  interventions  are  expected  to
increase horticulture production in the four western provinces by 10 percent at the end of year
five.

ii.

Veterinary Services

meet the requirements of potential livestock and meat importing countries. Veterinary services
provided  by  the  public  and  private  sectors  will  be  strengthened  to  enable  them  to  fulfil  their

Meat hygiene standards will be improved by providing training on international standards
84.
to  a  core  of  meat  inspectors  who  supervise  production  for  export  at  abattoirs  and  meat

responsibility.  This  will  contribute  to  an  improved  design  of  the  Government's  support  to

The  emerging  private  veterinary  sector  will  receive  training  in  animal  husbandry,  field

Finally, support will be given to the consultative process and changes in procedures and
87.
legislation necessary to establish a regulatory body (board of veterinarians) responsible for the
accreditation, registration, and discipline of all veterinarians and paraveterinarians. The services
will be conducted from the veterinary implementing agency until the first register is produced. At

iii.

Well Rehabilitation

88.
By  1995,  about  1,900  wells,  or  40  percent  of  the  wells  that  were  available  for  the
watering  of  livestock  and  supply  of  drinking  water  in  the  four  western  provinces  in  1989,  had
fallen  into  disrepair.  The  number  is  estimated  to  be  even  larger  today.  Most  affected  are  the
medium  and  deep  wells,  which  usually  consist  of  an  electrical  pump  powered  by  a  diesel
engine. To address the substantial need for an increased number of stock-watering points, the
subcomponent,  in  close  coordination  with  MFA's  well  rehabilitation  program  and  the  TA  on
pasture management (paras. 143-146), will support the rehabilitation of about 400 wells in the
four  western  provinces.  Since  nonoperational  wells  tend  to  be  in  varying  condition,  their
rehabilitation requirements may range from a few spare parts to the installment of new pumps
and  engines.  Average  well  repair  costs  are  estimated  at  $2,000.  Domestic  and  international
experts  in  close  cooperation  with  herder  communities  and  local  governments  will  assist  in
prioritizing  the  wells  to  be  rehabilitated  taking  into  account  both  drinking  water  and  livestock
watering  needs,  and  in  determining  the  most  suitable  and  cost-effective  way  of  well
rehabilitation.  Factors  to  be  considered  include  the  ownership/possession  of  the  well,  the
intended users and use patterns, the technical aspects, and the herders' willingness and ability
to pay water user fees to cover operation and maintenance costs. The well rehabilitation work
will be contracted out to provincial water supply boards or, in provinces where the boards have
been  privatized,  to  water  supply  companies.  The  herders  intending  to  use  a  rehabilitated  well
will receive training, and contracts will be made with groups of herders or individuals assigning
responsibility for well operation and maintenance, and collection of user fees.

89. Well rehabilitation will start in the second year of project implementation. During the first
year  a  mechanism  for  at  least  partially  recovering  well  rehabilitation  costs  will  be  developed.
Such mechanism may include the establishment of a well rehabilitation fund to be administered
by a financial institution, which would be responsible for recovering a certain percentage of the
cost. The recovered funds could be used to expand the well rehabilitation program.

Rural Communication Links

groups  are  most  likely  to  benefit  from  the  improved  credit  availability  as  members  of

policy measures is provided in Supplementary Appendix D. No significant negative effects were
identified.  Positive  environmental  impacts  are  anticipated  from  a  more  efficient  allocation  of

development of a more market-oriented, efficient, and sustainable agriculture sector. In addition,
incentives  will  be  provided  for  herder  households  to  substitute  their  current  strategy  of
maximizing  the  size  of  their  herds  with  a  strategy  for  improving  the  quality  and  productivity  of

VII.

BENEFITS AND RISKS

A.

Expected Impacts

1.

Project Justification

147.
The  Project  will  contribute  to  agricultural  growth  and  poverty  reduction  primarily  by
increasing incomes of agricultural producers. By supporting a production and marketing support
component  combined  with  a  credit  component,  the  Project  will  help  increase  productivity  and
profitability in herder and crop producing households in the four western provinces. In addition,
the credit component will support increased wheat production and productivity, as well as other
crop and livestock production in the two north-central provinces.

148. By its very nature, a sector development program such as the ASDP cannot be readily
summed up in a singe rate of return measurement as might be the case in agricultural projects
focusing  on  a  single  major  improvement,  such  as  irrigation.  Furthermore,  any  financial  and
economic  analysis  for  the  credit  component  can  only  be  indicative  because  subborrowers  are
encouraged to use the money they obtain for the most productive use available to them in their
agricultural  production  and  processing  enterprises.  However,  ample  evidence  exists,  as
presented  in  Appendix  12,  that  the  investment  Project  of  the  ASDP  will  be  profitable  for
individual  herders  and  crop  producers,  and  will  generate  new  wealth  for  the  economy  of
Mongolia.  Project  analysis  was  undertaken  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Guidelines  for  the
Economic Analysis of Projects.

2.

Results of Financial and Economic Analysis

149.
The  financial  and  economic  analysis  was  carried  out  in  four  parts,  including  for  the
subcomponents  on  (i)  livestock  production  (comprising  veterinary  services,  well  rehabilitation,
and in part rural communication links), (ii) cooperative development, (iii) the Green Revolution
Program,  and  (iv)  credit  to  purchase  improved  seed  for  wheat  production,  all  of  which  are

 36

independently  financially  and  economically  viable.  The  analyses  for  livestock  production  and
cooperative development were done using the rate of return analysis, and the analyses for the
Green Revolution Program and the credit for wheat seed using other estimates of financial and
economic worth.

Livestock production will provide significant quantifiable and nonquantifiable benefits that
150.
will  directly  contribute  to  the  goals  of  agricultural  growth  and  poverty  reduction.  Quantifiable
benefits  arise  because  of  improved  production  and  productivity  of  herder  households.  With
productivity in livestock production currently very low, relatively few inputs have the potential to
have  a  major  impact  in  the  short  term.  This  is  particularly  the  case  with  improved  livestock
health  through  the  use  of  veterinary  inputs.  Nonquantifiable  benefits  will  arise  from  improved
grazing  patterns  made  possible  by  the  well  rehabilitation  subcomponent.  The  environmental
benefits  resulting  from  reduced  pressure  on  the  pastures  currently  served  by  wells  may  be
significant in the longer term, but are difficult to quantify based on the data currently available.
The  financial  and  economic  analyses  focus  on  the  quantifiable  benefits  to  herder  households,
and yield a financial internal rate of return (FIRR) of 28 percent and an economic internal rate of
return (EIRR) of 38 percent. The resulting net present value, discounted at 12 percent, shows
that  about  MNT3,792  million  will  be  generated  for  the  economy.  The  EIRR  is  higher  than  the
FIRR  because  the  value  of  incremental  livestock  production  is  priced  at  border  prices,  while
much of the supporting services are nontraded. Results of the sensitivity analysis indicate that
EIRRs  remain  high  despite  significant  changes  in  key  variables,  including  increased  costs,
reduced benefits, or a combination of adverse conditions.

151.
Through  the  development  of  cooperatives,  especially  secondary  cooperatives,  herder
households  will  command  higher  prices  for  their  output  bringing  an  immediate  income  gain.
Herder  households  will  also  be  able  to  sell  their  animals  at  the  end  of  the  summer  instead  of
early in the season, so that they will be able to realize the advantage of a weight gain as a result
of good summer pasture. The investment in cooperatives proves to be quite profitable financially
and  good  economically,  even  with  very  low  participation  rates.  The  analysis  assumes  that
herder  households  marketing  through  the  cooperatives  will  be  those  with  sufficient  initiative  to
take  advantage  of 
the  productivity  gains  made  possible  by  the  livestock  production
subcomponents.  Thus  the  benefit  stream  is  the  increment  between  a  herder  household’s
income with productivity gain but without cooperative marketing as opposed to the income with
productivity  gain  and  marketing  through  secondary  cooperatives.  Only  half  of  the  herder
households benefiting from the productivity gains under the Project are assumed to also market
through  secondary  cooperatives.  With  these  assumptions  the  FIRR  is  estimated  to  be  41
percent,  and  the  EIRR  22  percent.  The  difference  between  the  two  arises  because  meat
products  from  secondary  cooperatives  are  assumed  to  command  a  quality  premium  at  the
domestic  market,  but  not  at  the  international  markets.  Economic  prices  are  thus  somewhat
lower  than  financial  prices,  and  the  benefit  from  an  incremental  gain  is  less;  in  contrast,  the
project  costs  are  not  very  different  in  the  financial  and  economic  analyses.  As  a  result,  the
incremental net benefit in the economic analysis is only about 40 percent of that in the financial
analysis. Results of the sensitivity analysis shows the cooperative development subcomponent
to  remain  viable  even  if  a  benefit  reduction  of  10  percent  or  a  cost  increase  of  10  percent

3.

Impact on Poverty

154.
The poverty analysis provided in the COS indicates that poverty in Mongolia is primarily
income-based: the result of insufficient incomes and lack of employment opportunities, and less
the result of education or health deprivation, social exclusion, or other lack of assets. The failure
of  economic  growth  to  reduce  poverty  is  a  reflection  of  the  problem  of  creating  broad-based
income and employment-generating activities.

The  ASDP  is  designed  to  increase  the  income  and  to  some  extent  the  employment
155.
opportunities of agricultural producers, both in provincial centers where poverty is highest, and
in  rural  areas.  In  provincial  centers,  poverty  is  strongly  correlated  with  unemployment.  In  rural
areas one of the main reasons for poverty is the large number of households with small herds,
with  100  animals  generally  considered  the  minimum  size  for  a  self-sustaining  household.  By
concentrating  the  activities  of  the  project  components  in  four  western  provinces  where  the
number of households with herds of less than 100 animals ranges from 40 to 60 percent, poor
people are expected to comprise at least one third of the beneficiaries.

156.
The most important subcomponents under the ASDP in terms of poverty impact are the
support  for  cooperative  development  and  the  support  for  the  Green  Revolution  Program.
According to information from cooperative associations, the members of cooperatives tend to be
mostly  households  with  smaller  herds.  Similarly,  the  target  group  of  the  Green  Revolution
Program are vulnerable groups including households headed by women and the unemployed in
provincial and district centers, and households with small herds, who graze their animals near
these centers and need additional income sources. The ASDP policy matrix is closely linked to
these  two  subcomponents  and  includes  policy  measures  to  provide  for  the  necessary
framework  for  the  successful  implementation  of  both  cooperative  development  and  the  Green
Revolution Program.

157. Appendix  13  presents  an  overview  of  the  poverty  situation  in  Mongolia,  and  a  poverty
impact  assessment  of  the  relevant  policy  measures  including  (i)  implementation  of  the
Cooperative  Law  and  Cooperative  Development  Program,  and  (ii)  reorientation  of  the  Green
Revolution Program. The analysis of these policy measures in terms of the effect on the labor
market,  prices,  access  for  the  poor,  and  transfers  shows  that  they  are  anticipated  to  have  a
positive impact on the poor. None of the other policy measures included in the reform program
are expected to have a significant adverse impact on the poor.

 B.

Risks and Safeguards

38

158. A  potential  risk  to  the  ASDP  policy  program  is  a  delay  in  implementing  some  of  the
policy  measures  under  the  reform  program.  The  delay  may  be  caused  by  institutional
weaknesses or economic uncertainties. Safeguards are built into the ASDP to minimize this risk.
A period of two years between the first and second tranches, and another two years between
the  second  tranche  and  the  end  of  the  program  have  been  set  to  give  adequate  time  for  the
completion of the policy reforms. In addition, many of the policy measures are closely linked to
activities proposed under the investment Project and associated TA, so that support is indirectly
provided for policy implementation.

159. A  potential  risk  to  the  investment  Project  involves  the  provision  of  inadequate
counterpart financing. The 1999 country portfolio review for Mongolia concluded that ADB's loan
portfolio  is  satisfactory,  with  implementation  generally  proceeding  on  schedule  despite  the
economic uncertainties, fiscal constraints, and general institutional weakness. The main current
and  likely  continuing  issue  facing  the  efficient  implementation  of  ADB-financed  projects  is  the
availability  and  timely  release  of  counterpart  funds.  The  Government  requires  assistance  to
address  the  budget’s  structural  problems  which  are  at  the  heart  of  the  current  budget
imbalance.  The  recently  approved  Governance  Reform  Program24  will  contribute  to  improving
public expenditure management.

160. A  potential  risk  for  the  credit  component  is  the  faltering  of  the  ongoing  financial  sector
and  banking  reform.  To  address  this,  implementation  of  the  Agricultural  Bank’s  business  plan
needs  to  proceed  on  schedule.  The  Post  Bank  must  undertake  training  to  start  lending  in  its
rural  branches  and  subbranches.  The  inclusion  of  Darhan-Uul  and  Selenge  in  the  credit
component  will  allow  other  banks  and  NBFIs  to  qualify  as  PFIs.  The  credit  component  is
designed to allow for flexibility for PFIs: any financial institution will be able to participate as long
as  it  meets  the  eligibility  criteria.  The  Government  is  committed  to  continuing  the  reforms  and
ensuring the necessary framework to allow for the restoration of lending services in rural areas.
The  Second  Financial  Sector  Program  in  cooperation  with  World  Bank's  Financial  Sector
Adjustment Credit, both approved in 2000, will help mitigate the risk of faltering financial sector
and banking reforms.

161. Successful  project  implementation  will  also  depend  on  the  capacity  of  the  national,
provincial, and district agricultural agencies. The ASDP includes ADB's first investment project
in Mongolian agriculture, and the second externally-funded loan executed by MFA. Experience
with  agriculture-related  agencies  in  other  transition  economies  has  shown  that  strengthening
capacity requires a long-term effort. Most project subcomponents include capacity building and
training activities. The project management component includes assistance to MFA to improve
monitoring and evaluation systems.

The  two  north-central  provinces  are  less  poor  than  the  western  provinces,  with  25

During the last decade, relatively little economic development has taken place in the four
western provinces as compared with the rest of the country. This contributed, particularly during

D.

Gender Issues

11.
Mongolia  is  characterized  by  high  gender  equity,  founded  in  nomadic  and  socialist
values.  Women  are  well-educated  and  well-represented  in  most  occupations,  and  have  equal
access  to  education  and  employment  opportunities.  Female  enrollment  is  higher  than  male
enrollment at most levels, including university education. During the transition period, however,
the economic and social independence of many women was undermined. The loss of jobs and
the breakdown of much of the social support system especially affected women. In rural areas
small service industries often had to close, and in urban areas state service industries were the
first  to  downsize  their  labor  force.  Women  were  disproportionally  affected  by  these  changes.
Commensurate with the expansion of the private sector, the informal sector grew, where women
now predominate.

12.
Poverty  is  particularly  severe  among  households  headed  by  women.  According  to  the
Living  Standards  Measurement  Surveys,  63  percent  of  such  households  were  poor  in  1995.
This  ratio  decreased  to  47  percent  in  1998.  In  1998,  about  25  percent  of  the  very  poor
households  and  18  percent  of  the  poor  households  were  headed  by  women.  Most  of  these
households were in urban areas (44 percent of Ulaanbaatar's poor households, and 53 percent
of  the  provincial  centers'  poor  households),  rather  than  in  rural  areas  (24  percent  of  poor
households).

13.
In the agriculture sector, there were some negative consequences for women resulting
from the privatization of livestock. Prior to privatization, women in negdels worked primarily as
dairy  maids  in  single-species  livestock  units.  Privatized  herds  are  usually  mixed  and  require
more  tending  and  processing  of  animal  products,  implying  more  work  for  women.  Herder
households headed by women tend to have smaller herds than herder households headed by
men, because they received fewer animals when animals were privatized. Given that there are
often  no  other  adults  in  the  households,  herder  households  headed  by  women  face  labor
shortages in critical times of the year. In addition, many of them had to sell their animals in order
to buy food and other necessities. When animal resources are depleted, the women often are
forced to work for wealthier herder households in exchange for food.

The Credit Line

The  investment  Project  of  the  Agriculture  Sector  Development  Program  will  comprise  a  credit

implemented in the provinces of Darhan-Uul, Dzavhan, Gobialtay, Hovd, Selenge, and Urs. The credit

Ministry  of  Food  and  Agriculture  (MFA),  Ministry  of  Finance  and  Economy  (MFE),  and    Bank  of

Objectives and Scope

The  technical  assistance  (TA)  is  closely  linked  to  the  Agriculture  Sector  Development

development  of  the  cooperative  system  as  cooperatives  offer  the  most  promising  avenue  for

marketing and other services to members. The limiting factors for improving livestock productivity

FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC ANALYSIS

A. 

Introduction

By  its  very  nature,  a  sector  development  program  such  as  the  Agricultural  Sector
1.
Development  Program  (ASDP)  cannot  be  readily  summed  up  in  a  single  rate  of  return
measurement  as  might  be  the  case  in  agricultural  projects  focusing  on  a  single  major
improvement, such as irrigation. Furthermore, any financial and economic analysis to the credit
component can only be indicative because subborrowers are free—indeed encouraged—to use
the  money  they  obtain  for  the  most  productive  use  available  to  them  in  their  agricultural
production or processing enterprises.

Nonetheless, ample evidence exists, as presented in this appendix, that the investment
2.
Project  of  the  ASDP  will  be  profitable  for  individual  herders  and  crop  producers,  and  will
generate new wealth for the economy of Mongolia well in excess of the ADB cut-off rate of 12
percent.  Analyses  are  presented  for  the  project  components  and  subcomponents  addressing
livestock  production  (including  veterinary  services,  well  rehabilitation,  and  in  part  rural
communication  links),  cooperative  development,  the  Green  Revolution  Program,  and  credit  to
purchase  improved  seed  for  wheat  production,  all  of  which  are  independently  financially  and
economically viable.

3.
The  Project  will  contribute  to  agricultural  growth  and  poverty  reduction  primarily  by
increasing incomes of agricultural producers. By supporting a production and marketing support
component  combined  with  a  credit  component,  the  Project  will  help  increase  productivity  and
profitability  in  herder  and  crop  producing  households  in  four  western  provinces,  including
Dzavhan,  Gobialtay,  Hovd,  and  Urs.  In  addition,  the  credit  component  will  support  increased
wheat  production and  productivity as well as other crop and livestock production in two north-
central provinces, including Darhan-Uul and Selenge.

B. 

Project Alternatives

In consultation with the Ministry of Food and Agriculture (MFA) and its predecessor the
4.
Ministry  of  Agriculture  and  Industry,  various  alternatives  for  the  location  and  design  of  the
Project were considered during project preparation. The choice of including four of the country’s
lowest  income  provinces  in  the  western  part  of  Mongolia  was  made  because  since  the
beginning of the transition most development has been taking place in the central region around
Ulaanbaatar.  Also  selecting  provinces  within  one  region  allows  for  close  consultation  among
stakeholders and joint activities, while keeping travel times and costs at a minimum.

The  livestock  subsector  dominates  the  rural  economy  of  the  four  western  provinces.
5.
Even though the herd size increased by more than 20 percent during the last decade, incomes
are very constrained. This is mainly due to (i) low productivity caused by low input use, with the
major  contributing  factors  being  the  lack  of  cash  and  credit,  limited  veterinary  input,  and  high
stocking rates (sheep equivalent units per hectare) aggravated by a large number of inoperative
stock-watering facilities; as well as (ii) marketing bottlenecks and the lack of market information.
The Project is designed to address these critical issues. The cooperative system is considered
to be the most promising channel to improve marketing in remote rural areas because a large
structure of primary cooperatives is  already in place and is in the process of being developed
with  the  support  of  the  Government  and  development  agencies  such  as  the  Deutsche
Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit (GTZ).

 77

Appendix 12, page 2

6.
In  the  crop  subsector,  the  Government’s  Green  Revolution  Program  has  supported
horticultural  production  to  improve  food  security  and  diversify  incomes.  In  the  four  western
provinces,  the  activity  was  mainly  taken  up  by  households  close  to  the  provincial  and  district
centers  where  unemployment  is  high,  and  by  vulnerable  groups  with  small  herds  that  graze
around these centers. Especially after the livestock disaster of the winter 1999/2000, horticulture
production has become an important activity for these groups to augment food reserves and to
barter  for  livestock  and  livestock  products,  and  was  therefore  included  as  a  project
subcomponent.

Responding  to  Government  concerns  about  declining  wheat  production,  the  Project’s
7.
credit  component  includes  the  two  important  wheat-producing  provinces  of  Darhan-Uul  and
Selenge.  This  will  allow  wheat  producers  to  borrow  to  purchase  improved  seed  and  perhaps
simple tillage equipment, or seed cleaners to clean seed from wheat saved by them to be used
in the following season.

C. 

Demand Analysis

8.
The  subcomponents  addressing  the  livestock  subsector  will  result  in  additional
production of fiber (cashmere and wool), hides and skins, and meat. Demand for cashmere by
the world market is considerable, with the People’s Republic of China (PRC) being the largest
importer  of  Mongolian  cashmere.  In  recent  years,  the  price  of  cashmere  has  been  very
favorable.  Exports  of  cashmere  increased  from  400  tons  in  1990  to  2,000  tons  in  1999.  One
result of the strong export demand for cashmere has been an increase in the proportion of goats
in livestock herds leading  to concerns in some areas of overgrazing since goats crop grasses
more  closely  than  other  livestock  species.  The  increased  production  of  meat  arising  from  the
Project is not projected to be large enough to influence domestic prices. Up until the mid-1990s,
the four western provinces exported meat mainly to the Russian Federation and in some cases
to the PRC. Export of meat to the PRC is currently not permitted because it is not included in
the  current  trade  agreement  with  the  PRC.  The  Project  will  train  veterinarians  in  international
standards of slaughter hygiene. Once the slaughter hygiene can meet international standards,
exports are expected to increase, especially to the substantial Siberian market.

The  Project 

includes  significant  support 

for  cooperatives,  especially  secondary
9.
cooperatives, to serve the needs of herder households in the four western provinces. This builds
on an existing widespread cooperative structure, although the cooperatives vary widely in their
effectiveness. Almost all agricultural cooperatives are primary cooperatives whose members are
herder households or individual herders. Agricultural cooperatives purchase agricultural produce
from  their  members,  including  cashmere,  sheep,  and  camel  wool,  livestock,  hides,  and  meat,
and sell them to mostly large processors. Cooperatives compete with rural traders from within
Mongolia  and  from  the  PRC  who,  especially  in  the  case  of  cashmere,  currently  purchase  at
relatively high prices but with little regard for product quality, and a high level of uncertainty for
producers.  In  this  situation,  cooperatives  can  be  successful  in  providing  marketing  with
reasonable  prices  and  a  high  degree  of  certainty  for  members.  When  purchasing  from  their
members,  cooperatives  can  take  quality  aspects  into  consideration,  thereby  providing  price
incentives for improving product quality. Rural households have a high demand for staple food
items,  such  as  flour,  sugar,  tea,  and  household  goods,  which  they  usually  obtain  from  rural
traders in relatively unfavorable barter exchanges for agricultural produce. Besides the supply of
basic consumer goods, cooperatives can also play an important role in organizing the supply of
necessary inputs for production activities, such as bulk purchase of winter fodder.

Promotion of cooperatives, especially secondary cooperatives, is an important subcomponent of

also  marketing  through  the  cooperatives.  Only  half  the  herder  households  benefiting  from  the

Causes  of  Poverty.  Until  1990  unemployment  and  poverty  were  virtually  unknown  in
1.
Mongolia, and inequality was very low. During the initial transition period in the beginning of the
1990s, the economy contracted sharply due to the withdrawal of Soviet assistance, equivalent
to  about  30  percent  of  gross  domestic  product  (GDP),  and  the  breakup  of  the  trading  system
with the member countries of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance. The collapse in the
state  budget  led  to  drastic  cuts  in  subsidies  and  welfare  programs,  and  this  pushed  many
households  below  the  poverty  line.  In  addition,  the  economic  restructuring  and  privatization
process  led  to  severe  retrenchment  in  public  sector  employment,  and  to  the  closure  of  many
nonviable  enterprises.  Although  much  of  the  shed  labor  force  was  absorbed  by  the  extensive
livestock  sector  and,  in  part,  by  the  growing  informal  economy,  underemployment  and
unemployment rose substantially. Furthermore, the privatization program for the collective herds
resulted  in  many  households  owning  a  below-subsistence  herd  size.  With  reduced  state  and
private  income,  both  formal  and  informal  social  safety  nets  faltered,  and  poverty  levels
increased rapidly.

2.

Government established a poverty line based on per capita income equivalent required to meet
a  daily  calorie  intake  of  1,872  kilo  calories  (Kcal)  per  capita  in  rural  areas,  and  1,992  Kcal  in
urban areas. The income-based poverty line was adjusted each year. Based on this measure,
the population living below the minimum living standard level was estimated to be 16 percent in

exception of Gobialtay, belonged to the poorest areas, with 43 percent of the population living
below the minimum living standard level in Hovd, 41 percent in Dzavhan, and 34 percent in Urs.
The estimate for Gobialtay was 16 percent.
